¹ See Nineteenth Century and After, October, 1915.

For various reasons it is highly desirable that
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> should understand this. The services
the Masters render us, in harmony with the
influence of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> hierarchy to which they
belong, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be rendered just as zealously,
however ignorant we might be of the benefits
conferred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> us. <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> agents do not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> for
reward. But if the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> is rightly understood
it will be seen that we are the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
be richly rewarded, if we became cognizant of the
benefits conferred, and were, so to speak,
grateful accordingly. It is true, indeed, that if
such gratitude were widely felt and associated
with clear comprehension of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> in which our
Elder Brethen, the Unseen Masters, are struggling
on super-physical planes with the Powers of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span>
on our behalf, they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> in a certain degree be
strengthened in the struggle they are carrying
on. Success does not depend on such reinforcement
of strength; that is certain and assured, but the
duration of the struggle, on which the duration
of the War depends, might be to some extent
affected in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> above described.
Meanwhile the more subtle reward we should secure
by gratefully appreciating the protection
afforded us has to do with a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span>
familiar to the occultist, and of growing
importance to humanity as evolution proceeds.

Spiritual help of the kind affecting the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> welfare and progress of each <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> unit
can only be rendered by <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> <span class="t1 t4 t8 t16 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> in response
to aspiration from the level of this life. We
must look up, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> that they may look down,
in the manner affecting individual progress. The
progress of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> collectively will go on,
anyhow, when the terrible crisis through which it
is passing is over, because some of us will
assuredly be looking up, and these in the course
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> will drag on the rest. In that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> the
evolution and progress of the race, as a whole,
is provided for, but it will be appreciably
accelerated if those who look up, in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span>
described, become appreciably more numerous than
the mere laws of average <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> ensure. And the
acceleration of progress, as regards the upwardlookers themselves, might be more remarkable than
they can readily imagine. Not indeed that such a
spiritually selfish motive ought to be mainly
operative in bringing about the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of feeling
that should prevail. From the point of <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of
the mere occult student on this plane of life, it
is disgusting that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> multitude around us
should be, so to speak, sopping up the benefits
conferred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> them by the Masters collectively
and failing even to be decently thankful. Any
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> who may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> cognizance of this that I am
writing would, I fancy, laugh at the notion that
they could be supposed to want gratitude, but
none the less all that I have <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> above holds
good, and anyhow I know that they are eager to
help all who are ready to be helped, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> are more than pleased when such help is
consciously invoked. At earlier stages of the
world's growth they had to remain concealed. The
stake and the torture chambers of the Church
awaited those who tried to proclaim any <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span>
nobler than that of the priests. The Masters had
to bide their time. But their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> has now come.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is ripe to have its religious <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span>
levelled up to harmonize with the sublime
realities of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> government, and the dangers

of allowing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> to be <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> from
medieval corruption have at last become
negligible.
A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deal in advance of the modern occult
development, a <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> A Suggestive Inquiry
into the Hermetic Mystery, published fifty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span>
ago, gave out some information about alchemy (the
occultism of the Middle Ages) that some devotees
of that study at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> dangerously
frank. The author answers the criticism by
anticipation in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> which I will leave, in
conclusion, as applicable also to such
explanations as it has been my privilege to put
forward:
If we have been <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> in our expositions the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> was
not the more reckless but because the thresholds of
ignorance are already overpast. . . . They are all now
incredulous who were formerly dreaded in their belief,
and under that safe guardianship we leave them happily
supine in the conviction that our conduct will neither be
attractive nor intelligible, much less practically
useful, to the profane multitude of mankind.

THE OCCULTISM IN TENNYSON'S POETRY
A FEW among the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> host of his devotees who,
besides appreciating the varied beauties of
Tennyson's poetry, are in touch with modern
developments of the <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">Higher</span> Occultism, will be
alive to the significance of some hints scattered
through his writings showing how he, in advance
of modern developments, intuitively divined some
important principles now emerging from obscurity
into the light. Even highly cultured and
appreciative readers, unless also students of
occultism, may <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> them by unnoticed. Sir Alfred
Lyall, for example, in his generally admirable
survey of Tennyson's work, contributed to the
series of "English <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> of Letters," overlooks
some glaring hints of the kind in question, while
actually dealing with the mere literary charm of
one poem mainly devoted to the present
elucidation of occult ideas.
The elucidation of the passages <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> hinting at
hitherto hidden mysteries of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> is
the purpose of the present article, but it must
not be held to imply that the writer seeks to
enrol Tennyson in the ranks of professed
occultists. Of course, the splendour of his
genius shone chiefly in his treatment of purely
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> emotion. And we, who have passed through
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> by <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> with the poetic stream of his
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> that flowed through the greater part of
the last century, have derived our most intense
pleasure from the perfection of his earlier
verse, apart from the beauty of the thoughts it
conveyed. Then came the Idylls of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> in
their stately magnificence, but they have nothing
to do with occultism. A truly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> poet can
never be a specialist in any one vein of
creation, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> in whatever vein he is
following, Tennyson seems for the moment to be a
specialist in that. The Lady of Shalott, The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Day</span>
Dream, The Lotos-Eaters, and many others of that
period, surpass in their musical charm any

previous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> in English literature, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
Byron and Moore sometimes touched the same level.
And the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> in which Locksley Hall might be
criticized, like Hamlet, as "full of
quotations," shows how Tennyson was a specialist
among poets in coining phrases that linger in
universal memory, while the Idylls of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span>
lead some of us to forget that the supreme <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span>
of blank <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> was equally unrivalled in dealing
with rhyme. But after all, however highly we may
appreciate his art, that merely renderd the
surface worthy of the substance of his poetry.
So much in advance to show that the interest some
of us may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> in the flashes of occult
inspiration to be discerned in Tennyson's poems
need not separate us from the sympathy of
worshipers who live in a more familiar
atmosphere. Nor from the point of <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of occult
students, who have profited by the flood of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>
let in of late on mysteries previously obscure,
will the flashes in question show that Tennyson
was completely in possession of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> which
humbler mortals at the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> are inheriting
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> an effort. Indeed, innumerable allusions
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> and the hereafter in In Memoriam are
hardly tinged with any philosophy deeper than
ordinary religious feeling, and in The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> Voices
the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> voice, which sweeps away the
comfortless reasoning of the first, offers merely
A little hint to solace Woe A hint, a whisper breathing low,

a mere "hidden hope." And <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> the same poem
contains a <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> that might almost be reckoned
among the flashes of inspiration, suggesting the
theory of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> now reduced to a scientific shape,
and gradually winning consent in all directions the doctrine of Reincarnation:

I cannot make this <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> plain,
But I <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> shoot, howe'er in vain,
A random arrow from the brain.
It may be that no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is found,
Which only to one engine bound
Falls off, but cycles always round.
As old mythologies relate,
Some draught of Lethe might await
The slipping thro' from <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> to state.
As here we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> in trances, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span>
Forget the dream that happens then,
Until they fall in trance again.

I need not expand the quotation. The poem from
which it comes will be familiar to all
Tennysonian enthusiasts, and the <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> to which
I <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> attention embodies a <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> far more
fully treated in later utterances; but before
dealing with them it is worth while to turn back
to one of his very earliest fragments entitled
The Mystic, <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> when Tennyson could not have
been more than seventeen, and to be found, I
think, in one edition of the Poems by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span>
Brothers. It begins:
Angels have talked with him and shown him thrones,
Ye knew him not, he was not one of ye,
Ye scorned him with an undiscerning scorn,
Ye could not read the marvel in his eye,
The still serene abstraction he <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hath</span> felt.

Skipping a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> deal to the same general effect,
we come to the final lines, which are as follows:
How could ye know him? Ye were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span>
The narrower circle: he had well-nigh reached
The last which with a region of white flame
Pure <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> heat into a larger air
Upburning and an ether of black blue
Investeth and engirds all other lives.

As far as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> of this poem is concerned we
need not trace any of the lines, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> some of
them are dignified and worthy of the subject, to
anything in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of verbal inspiration. As
the Memoir by his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> shows us, Tennyson wrote
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> when he was only eight <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> old, and the
Memoir gives us some fairly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> and harmonious
examples of his boyhood's work, never published
during his life, <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> when he was fourteen or
fifteen. Everyone familiar with the principle of
Reincarnation will readily understand that so
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> a poet as Tennyson must have been a poet
already in former lives, and could not but <span class="t4 t6 t7 t9 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 hoverable">bring</span>
over the capacity for poetic expression, so that
inspiration, merely conveying an idea, could rely
on the new personality to clothe it in
appropriate language. Thus, although the ideas
underlying The Mystic can hardly be regarded as
originating in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> of a boy of seventeen,
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> conveying them may have been entirely
his own.
The description of The Mystic is not appropriate
to any one on the ordinary plane of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> to whom
that term might apply. Writers on the
philosophical system generally <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
"Mysticism" are "Mystics" in one sense, but may
not have any characteristics resembling those
described in the poem. Those are the
characteristics which - with others - belong to
the highly evolved "Elder Brethen" of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span>
race - now generally spoken of as the Masters of
Wisdom, of whom - since they themselves have
communicated more freely than in former times
with the ordinary plane of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> - we have come to
know a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deal. That they inspire many modern
writers with ideas for them to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> up in the
progress of literature, art, and science is now
clearly realized by their pupils in occultism.
Conventional thinking has hitherto made at once
too much and too little of inspiration. It has
been conceived as only of very rare occurrence in

connection with writings of a sacred character,
its frequency being <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> very limited, while its
source is <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> of as altogether Divine. It is
really of constant occurrence and emanates from
all levels of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Hierarchy. The extent to
which writers and artists (those with some lofty
purpose in their work) are "helped" by invisible
beings, on a <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> plane of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> than their own,
can hardly be exaggerated, so there is indeed
little <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> to be surprised at finding a
youthful poet of Tennyson's promise under
inspiration from a very early period.
But the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> was not ripe in the year 1826 for
the gift of any detailed information concerning
the actual constitution of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Hierarchy,
with its varied levels of dignity and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and
intricate agencies. In 1892, towards the close of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> poet's life, conditions had changed in
a very remarkable degree. And the flashes of
inspiration to which Tennyson lent himself then
became wonderfully distinct. A few verses to be
found in the volume published in that year, and
entitled By an Evolutionist, are deeply
suggestive. We read as follows:
The
And

And

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> let the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of a brute to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> of a man,
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> said "Am I your debtor?"
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> - "Not yet: but make it as clean as you can,
then I will let you a better."

Occult students will recognize in these few lines
a flood of significant allusion. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> alone
may have no deep <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> for readers unfamiliar
with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> principles hinted at, but for
those who know more they are richly significant.
They include, to begin with, the fundamental idea
that humanity is evolved from humbler animal
life, and beyond this they recognize the method
of that evolution - the transfer of <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">Consciousness</span>
from Lower to <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">Higher</span> Vehicles as the consequence
of its own craving for the higher. They recognize

more than that indeed - a deep and supremely
important idea concerning the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of
consciousness. This is one of the latest
developments of advanced occult teaching.
<span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">Consciousness</span> - that supreme mystery that baffles
all physiological research - is uniform in its
character throughout all manifestations of life.
There is only one kind of consciousness: that of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t1 t4 t8 t16 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> and of the animal <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> is the
same throughout. Its effective value depends on
the vehicle in which it is working. In the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span>
of an animal it has greatly expanded capacities.
In the vehicles of <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> belonging to
<span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> planes it finds these capacities again
expanded to an extent which ordinary humanity, at
the average stage reached in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> at the
present time, cannot even grasp in imagination.
At every stage of the process the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> works.
Any given volume of <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> any
given vehicle, gradually becoming an
individuality, establishes a claim on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> for
an improved vehicle, by making the best possible
<span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of the one it has got. "Make it as clean as
you can, and then I will let you a better."
We can understand the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> best by concentrating
attention on humanity first. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> at an early
stage of his progress cannot ascend to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
heights of achievement. He may be fit for little
more than the rougher manual <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span>
life. But being by that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> a man, he has - if
only a glimmering - perception of the difference
between right and wrong. He follows the guidance
of this perception. He makes the vehicle of his
<span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> (which is himself) "as clean as he
can." In his next incarnation he infallibly
acquires "a better." <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> above quoted,
among other ideas, clearly recognizes the
principle of Reincarnation, which Tennyson
evidently accepted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> reserve and worked
with continually. In the Memoir of Alfred, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span>
Tennyson by his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> we are told that he <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> to Section xliii. of In Memoriam, which runs

as follows:
If the immediate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> after <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> be only sleep, and the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> between this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and the next should be folded
like a flower in a night slumber, then the rememberance
of the last night remains as the smell and colour do in
the sleeping flower, and in that <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> the memory of our
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">love</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> last as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> live as pure and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of my friend until after it was
unfolded at the breaking of the morn when the sleep was
over.

In writing this Tennyson was evidently
concentrating <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> on the idea of rebirth and
the recovery of the love-relations of the
previous life. Even if the intervening period
were merely a sleep the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Ego <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> reappear
in the awakening life. The more scientific <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span>
of reincarnation, of course - while confidently
recognizing that idea - realizes the immense
importance of the intervening <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span>
planes. Sometimes, indeed, if the Ego is at a
humble stage of its expansion, the intervening
period, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> restful and happy, is little
better than a blissful sleep. In others it
affords magnificent opportunities for the
cultivation of intellectual or artistic capacity.
True, such growth can only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> as a
consequence of some effective seed of aspiration
or effort sown in the previous <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> life, but
even minute seeds of that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> are nuclei from
which splendid consequences may ensue, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> in
any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> interfering with the revival of old loves
and even minor friendships dating back to the
past. The disregard of this important aspect of
the subject operates to render the idea of
reincarnation unattractive to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who
understand it imperfectly. They think of
themselves beginning a new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> all alone as it
were. This is a ridiculous misapprehension of the
natural law. A moment's <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> should show that
probability points to the idea that generations
living about the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> will - on the average

- get through their intervening lives on <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span>
planes, and be ready for reincarnation at about
the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> later on. Where personal ties of
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">love</span> or even less powerful affinities associate
Egos together, their return <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> becomes a
<span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of certainty. Adequately trained
clairvoyance is equal to the task of verifying
that principle, and tracing back, even through
ages in the past, the former lives of living
people.
Whenever genuine mutual affection unites <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
on this plane of life, they are always found to
have been in affectionate relationship in former
lives also. There may have been considerable
differences in intellectual growth even, but the
love-tie is supreme, and the ingenuity of the
natural <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> - or of those who guide the natural
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> - is equal to the emergency in such cases,
and to much more complicated problems of
"Karma" - the convenient term which embraces,
among other meanings, the necessity that moral
causes engendered in one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> shall reap their
appropriate consequences in lives of later date.
Now let us turn to the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> of the brief
poem, of which the first has been quoted above:
I have climb'd to the snows of Age, and I gaze at a field
in the Past,
Where I sank with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> at times in the sloughs of a
low desire,
But I hear no yelp of the beast, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is quiet at
last
As he stands on the heights of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> with a glimpse of
a height that is higher.

The last few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of the last line - "a glimpse
of a height that is higher" - hint unmistakably
at the sublime possibilities of Initiation. There
is no finality in the vast process of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span>
evolution, but there are recognizable stages. The
perfect <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> has reached one of those stages, from

which he looks forward to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> attainment
transcending any condition that can be limited by
the term humanity. I need not attempt to
elaborate that idea; but we shall see <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> to
believe that the poet knew more of the height
that is <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> than he found it possible to put
into words.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> under which <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> in
humanity seeks and secures better and better
vehicles operates also throughout the lower
kingdoms. It is not easily traced through animal
and vegetable manifestations, but even faintly
understood it illuminates the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> doctrine of
Evolution. Occult students at one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> were
inclined to <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> fault with the Darwinian
presentation of the idea, as ignoring the
evolution of <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> going on concurrently
with the evolution of form. We see now that the
evolution of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> defines the evolution of
consciousness. <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">Consciousness</span> is very far from
being a mere attribute of the form, as some
materialistic scientists of the last century
imagined, but the expression of its infinite
capacities depends on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> in which it is
working. This <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the subject is worthy of
protracted treatment; but there are other poems
that claim examination.
A little fragment - merely <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> verses - entitled
The Making of Man, is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> worth attention, but
does not do more that reiterate some of the ideas
in the verses last discussed. It recognizes the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of the tiger and the ape as necessarily
manifesting in humanity at first, but
Prophet-eyes may catch a <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> slowly gaining on the
shade,
Till the peoples all are one and all their voices blend
in choric
Hallelujah to the Maker - "It is finished. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is made."

We may now turn to the poem which is the fullest
expression of occult inspiration among all that
suggest that origin - The Ancient Sage. This,
indeed, includes evidence showing that Tennyson
in his own <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> had attained to definite
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> relating to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> conditions far
transcending those familiar to the average
humanity of our period. The Ancient Sage was
published in the volume entitled "Tiresias and
other Poems," just preceding the latest of all "Demeter and other Poems." The "Sage," obviously
a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> of Wisdom, criticises a "scroll" by a
young companion who has embodied sceptical,
almost materialistic, views in very graceful
verse. The scroll recognizes that "the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is
fair in hue,"
But <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> to-day is fancy's fool
As <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hath</span> ever been.
The nameless Power, or Powers, that rule
Were never <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> or seen.

The <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">Master</span> comments on this:
If <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> wouldst hear the Nameless, and wilt dive
Into the Temple-cave of <span class="t6 t13 t22 t23 t28 hoverable">thine</span> own self,
There, brooding by the central altar, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span>

By which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> wilt abide, if <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> be wise.

The scroll still quarrels with the mystery.
And since - from when this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> began The Nameless never came
Among us, never spake with man,
And never named the Name.

And the Sage answers with almost the best <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span>

After a <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> in the scroll relating to the
darkness and miseries of life, the Sage replies:
Who knows but that the darkness is in man?
The doors of Night may be the gates of Light;
For wert <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> or blind or deaf, and then

The splendours and the voices of the world!

And this leads up to the most striking <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> in
the poem, in which the Sage - in this <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span>
Tennyson himself - got "out of the body," to <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span>
a phrase familiar to occult students, by adopting
a method with which they are quite familiar. This
consists of self-induced hypnotism <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> on by
repeating - alone and aloud - one's own name. The
repetitions may have to be very numerous, running
perhaps into hundreds, and even then the effort
may be futile unless the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> making it has
some psychic potentialities in his nature. But
granting that last condition, it is an effective
process, and one which Tennyson seems to have
been almost in the habit of using. His reference
to it in the poem before us is as follows:
for more than once when I
Sat all alone, revolving in myself
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> that is the symbol of myself,

The mortal limit of the Self was loosed,
And past into the Nameless, as a cloud
Melts into Heaven. I touched my limbs, the limbs
Were strange not mine - and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> no shade of doubt,
But utter clearness, and thro' loss of Self
The gain of such large <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> as match'd with ours
Were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> to spark - unshadowable in words,
Themselves but shadows of a shadow world.

I cannot identify any other allusion in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
range of Tennyson's poetry that directly relates
to experiences of this nature, but in the Memoir
his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Son</span> tells us that
in some phases of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> and feeling his idealism tended
more decidedly to mysticism. He wrote: "A kind of waking
trance I have frequently had quite up from boyhood when I
have been all alone. This has generally come <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> me
through repeating my own name <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> times to
myself silently, till all at once, as it were out of the
intensity of the <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> of individuality, the
individuality itself seemed to dissolve and fade away
into a boundless being, and this not a confused <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> but
the clearest of the clearest, the surest of the surest,
the weirdest of the weirdest, utterly beyond words, where
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> was an almost laughable impossibility, the loss of
personality (if so it were) seeming no extinction but the
only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> life! This might be said to be the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> which
St. Paul describes, 'Whether in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> I cannot tell,
or <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> out of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> I cannot tell!'" He continued:
"I am ashamed of my feeble description. Have I not said
the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> is utterly beyond words? But in a moment when I
come back to my normal <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of 'sanity' I am ready to
fight for mein liebes Ich and hold that it will last for
aeons of aeons." In the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> he said that there might
be a more intimate communion than we could dream of
between the living and the dead, at all events for a

So the spiritualists may fairly claim Tennysonian
sanction for the fundamental principle of their
belief, which indeed is quite in harmony with the
views of advanced occult students, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> some of
early date were misled into a needlessly hostile
mistrust of the system, apt in some cases to be
itself rather misleading, but which - as broadly

designed to assure a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> drifting at one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
into materialsim that there is another <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> after
this, and so on - was a generous gift to
civilization from levels of <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> wisdom.
Readers of the Memoir will derive, from a very
unexpected source, confirmation of the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that
Tennyson made frequent <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of the repeated-name
method of attaining <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> illumination. It
appears that the author asked Professor Tyndall
to make some contribution to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in hand. In
the course of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> answer he says:
I looked up the <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of my first visit to Farringford,
and there to my profound astonishment I found described
that experience of your father's which, in the mouth of
the Ancient Sage, was made the ground of an important
argument against materialism and in favour of personal
immortality eight-and-twenty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> afterwards. . . . If
you turn to your father's <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the wonderful <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span>
of <span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> super-induced by thinking of his own
name and compare it with the argument of the Ancient Sage
you will see that they refer to one and the same
phenomenon.

Each injunction will be familiar to readers of
theosophical books, and a fortiori to all
students of the <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">Higher</span> Occultism, and that last
phrase, "Do-well will follow thought," is an
almost amusing reflection of a more elaborate
doctrine <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> forth in certain manuals that
profess to guide candidates for initiation in the
<span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> mysteries. They are told first to purify
thought, and secondly to purify conduct. From the
commonplace point of <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> that seems putting the
cart before the horse, but action may sometimes
be thoughtless, and then if it were avoided for
no definite <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> probably be repeated
for no definite reason. If purified <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span>
preceded its avoidance, the cure <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be
permanent.
It is needless to carry on further the search for
occult allusions in Tennyson's poetry. Fainter
hints, in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> of those already quoted,
might be pointed out in poems less definitely
infused with occult inspiration than The Ancient
Sage, but the broad conclusion to be derived from
them all is sufficiently <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> established. The
deeper mysteries of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> were still
veiled from general <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> during the greater
part of Tennyson's splendid literary activity. It
was not his task to tear down the veil
completely, nor did the rifts he made in it here
and there afford his readers anything resembling
that scientific comprehension of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> natural
truths lying behind it which many of us have
ultimately reached. This attainment inaugurates a
new era of thought. But Tennyson intuitively
forecast the revelation impending. And perhaps

for the cultured classes of this period, slow
hitherto to appreciate the significance of the
<span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">Higher</span> Occultism, the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that its development
was so clearly foreshadowed in the writings of a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> so universally reverenced as Tennyson, may
guide modern sympathies into regions of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span>
which they might never have explored but for that
august leadership.

CREEDS MORE OR LESS CREDIBLE
SINCE the amusing period when Bishop Colenso
discovered that the hare does not chew the cud as the author of the Pentateuch had supposed the "Allegory," on the banks of the Nile and
elsewhere, has been busy chewing the primitive
<span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> previously content to accept
statements in the Bible as necessarily true, even
when somewhat surprising. Tempers were often lost
during the discussions of the Colenso and Darwin
days, but Allegory has proved a more goodhumoured beast than he was <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> to be at
first, so that critics and the Church can give
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> now with a superficial pretence of being
friends in reality. Beyond this, indeed, the
attitudes of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> on both sides are undergoing
change. The ribald scoffer is extinct. The D.D.
who still attributes the sufferings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span>
to Eve's conversation with the Serpent hides
quietly in cathedral towns. Science and Theology
are on the terms that Talleyrand described as
established between himself and the Host, when he
raised his hat to a Roman Catholic procession:
"Nous nous saluons mais nous ne parlons pas." And
happily these relations are still improving.
Science, of the old materialistic order, has had
to endure many shocks of late. A police
magistrate some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> ago refused to believe
overwhelming testimony in favour of a
spiritualist medium on the ground that it was
contrary to the known laws of Nature. The members
of the Royal <span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> are no longer so sure of
having completely catalogued those laws. And the
doubt makes them even respectful to the theory of
miracles. After all, turning <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> into wine is
child's play compared with the miracle
accomplished whenever artificial incubation turns
an egg into a chicken. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> who still
disbelieve in the phenomena of genuine
spiritualism - as puzzling as any records in
Christian story - must guard their ignorance very
carefully if they wish to preserve their

opinions. Science in all directions is
negotiating with the unseen, and the <span class="t8 t12 t17 hoverable">wise</span>
churchman realizes that some concessions on his
part may lead to a settle peace, promising
protection for institutions and substantial
interests he sometimes felt to be in danger from
the battering ram. Already there is an entente
more or less cordiale between the enlightened
<span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">Free</span> Thinker - shedding the folly of denying
whatever he does not understand - and the
churchman who knows that he must adapt his <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span>
to the uniformites of Nature, that it is often
unsafe to insist that "sacred" writings always
mean what they seem to say.
But questions have arisen that are more
embarrassing than the reconciliation of Scripture
with obvious <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> facts. And these challenge
statements that cannot <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> sanctuary in any
theory of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> inspiration. The language of the
Creeds must at all events be ascribed to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span>
authorship. This is complicated and to some
extent obscure, but in criticizing the Creeds we
are not in trouble with any theory of verbal
inspiration from <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> levels. The Revised
Version of the Bible - humbly attempting to
correct a few gross errors of translation - has
(according to a familiar anecdote) been treated
with faint praise by a sturdy exponent of the
early <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> who preferred "God's own words." But
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> adopted to define Christian belief at
Nicæa in A.D.325 were simply those of certain
bishops, who prevailed over other bishops
desirous of using different words, so we cannot
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> <span class="t4 t6 t7 t9 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 hoverable">bring</span> inspiration into the story. Again, the
Nicene Creed was preceded by an extensive "creed
literature" - to <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> the phrase of an orthodox
writer, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be scarcely possible now
to identify any writing as the first attempt to
put Christian belief on paper. Nor does the
importance of the subject at the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
turn <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> its historical aspect. The question
arising is this: Do the Creeds, as they are put

into the mouths of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who attend church at
the present day, express beliefs they can
possibly be expected to entertain? The question
may fairly be described as having arisen, because
it has been recently the subject of
correspondence in The Times. Canon Glazebrook in
a <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> The <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">Faith</span> of a Modern Churchman
says that the clauses in the Apostles' Creed "Born of the Virgin Mary" and "The <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> He
rose again from the dead" - can legitimately be
interpreted "symbolically." The Bishop of Ely, in
a letter addressed to Canon Glazebrook and also
published in The Times, refuses to accept this
view, and supports his refusal by quoting a
resolution adopted by "the bishops of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
Anglican Communion assembled at the Lambeth
Conference in 1908," which runs as follows: "The
Conference in <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of tendencies widely shown in
writings of the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> hereby places on
record its conviction that the historical facts
stated in the Creeds are an essential part of the
<span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> of the Church." Canon Glazebrook, in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span>
letter published in The Times of May 21, does not
argue the question on its merits but quotes
episcopal sayings that deprecate undue
limitations on freedom of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> and inquiry,
and attributes to the Bishop of Oxford a <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of
the Ascension which he summarizes in this way:
"Our <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> could not, for astronomical reasons of
which the disciples were ignorant, physically
ascend into Heaven. But in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> give to them a
right conception of His change of <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> He rose
to a moderate height in the air, and then so
veiled Himself behind a cloud that they believed
Him to have gone right up into the vault of the
sky." If the Bishop is fairly represented by this
summary the suggestion needs expansion. What was
the later course of events? When our Lord, having
deluded His disciples in the manner described,
wanted to come down again, how did He conceal His
reappearance? But while the Bishop's hypothesis
tempts further comment, this might seem wanting
in due reverence for the main idea concerned, so

no more on that subject need be said for the
moment.
And <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> that line of speculation in reference to
alleged occurrences that outrage common sense, is
one into which it is easy to be driven if <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
are content to think of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> as simply
consisting of that which appeals to the five
senses, even <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> may be vaguely
regarded as bathed in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> conditions
intangible as Thought, out of relation with Space
or Time, <span class="t22 t23 t28 hoverable">offering</span> nothing to the imagination that
can prefigure a future existence, except of a
kind to be spoken of with bated breath and
avoided as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> as possible. Only for those,
happily a large and increasing number, who
comprehended more or less completely the
intervening conditions of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> lying between
the dense manifestation of the <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> plane and
the "incomprehensible" (though not less real)
conditions of exalted planes - only by virtue of
their superior enlightenment is it possible to
get rid - first of the dread commonly connected
with the process of passing on, and secondly of
the embarrassment arising from occasional
occurrences which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> such enlightenment must
either be disbelieved in defiance of evidence or
dealt with by some grotesquely foolish
explanation.
That idea applies very forcibly to the study of
the Creeds. The writers who reduced them to their
present shape may have been using <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> plane
language in a metaphorical sense, or they may
simply have swallowed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> hesitation
statements absurd on their face. But in either
<span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> we have to recognize, in the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of modern
occult knowledge, that somewhere in the back
history of the Creeds such <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> must have
been in the possession of some <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> or persons
who inspired the earliest writers on the subject.
And we reach, with the same confidence, the
conclusion that current versions of the Creeds

have been the product of painfully clumsy
editing. Such <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> could only have been carried
out properly by editors saturated with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span>
of natural conditions unseen by the multitude,
while the actual editors were certainly not of
that type. As a mere first illustration of that
idea we may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> the few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> in the Apostles'
Creed about the Resurrection and the Ascension:
"The <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> He rose again from the dead; He
ascended into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and sitteth on the right
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hand</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> the Father," etc. For <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who can
only think of a Being still in touch with the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> as of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t21 hoverable">flesh</span> and bones, the statement
must either be rejected altogether as fabulous,
or must lead to conceptions which, followed out
in detail, are deplorably downgrading. But
directly we begin to understand how <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span>
personalities may function in <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> consciousness,
after escaping (for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> or for good) from
imprisonment in the <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> - functioning
in another available vehicle, the astral <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> we see <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> shed on alleged phenomena otherwise
inexplicable. Many of us know now that natural
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> even provides for the temporary
materialization of the astral <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> so that it may
