conviction, that in no cases will the results
ensue from fanatical rules about eating and
drinking. The finest clairvoyants and psychics I
have known - and I have been priviliged to know a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> many - are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who laugh at all such
rules and <span class="t28 hoverable">eat</span> whatever they <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> by experience
keeps them in the best health. I am assured on

high authority that that is the only sound rule
to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> with. Our bodies are the instruments we
have to make <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of in this life, and whatever
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> we have to do, we can do it best by keeping
the instrument in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> order. It should go
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> saying that no one worth talking about
makes pleasure the test of what is best for him
to <span class="t28 hoverable">eat</span> or drink.
But if it is useless for most <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> even to
think of cultivating "latent" faculties in
themselves, how does the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> affect
them? In an extremely important way! The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> at
large knows nothing of the conditions that have
been reached by some members of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> family
- that may be reached eventually by all in some
future <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> - and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> which Theosophists are
priviliged to carry on is the dissemination of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> on this subject which they, if they
avail themselves of the opportunities for study
which the Theosophical Movement has provided, are
in a positon to promote. The laws governing the
gradual development of latent faculties in the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> family to which we belong constitute a
mighty science. I have said that we cannot all
make ourselves clairvoyant, but we can all, if we
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> advantage of our opportunities, become
proficient theoretically in that science; able to
help on multitudes of others so far less
priviliged than ourselves. And that is certainly
one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> - I lean to think it is the only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> - in
which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who in the current <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> are
beginning to be anxious about their latent
faculties can really provide for their growth.
Amplifying the above generalities, the first
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t16 t20 t21 t22 t23 hoverable">thing</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Theosophist has got to do is to
understand the goal to be aimed at - in other
words, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in Nature, the condition and
powers and functions of those whom we <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> of
now as "Masters of the White Lodge." I do not
much like the phrase, but it will serve for the
moment. In the early <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> of the movement we were

all led to say to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> thinking of joining the
Society: "It does not <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> you believe
in the Adept Brotherhood or not." And it did not
<span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> then. We felt that membership in the
<span class="t1 hoverable">Society</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> surely lead them sooner or later to
acquire this essential belief. If it does not,
they might really employ their energies elsewhere
to better advantage. Do my readers realize, I
wonder, how it came to <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> that "Esoteric
Buddhism" sent a thrill through the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> on its
first appearance? That was not merely or chiefly
because the sketch it gave of occult science met
an intellectual need, but because it made <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
think of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> Adepts, and that gave them a
chance of driving home a return current of
thought. They cannot begin such intercourse. The
first appeal must come from the aspiring <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span>
Ego. But once that aspiration is kindled, any
results may ensue.
Now, of course, those who profit by later
theosophical literature may learn much more about
the Masters than they could gather from the first
book. That, like every other theosophical <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> I
have ever looked at, is replete with
imperfection, for we who endeavour to interpret
the rudiments of occult science are working on
the threshold of infinity.
But there is much known now that was quite
unknown to the early leaders of the movement,
about the White Lodge and the methods of approach
to it, and those are the subjects and ideas
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> should concern themselves with if they
desire, in an intelligent way, to carry out our
<span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> - to "investigate" the laws of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> governing the development of the faculties
and powers latent in Man.

THE BORDERLAND OF SCIENCE
ASTRONOMY, OVERT AND OCCULT
1. - NEBULÆ

AN intelligent survey of our present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span>
and theories concerning nebulæ seems to have been
given lately to an American astronomical <span class="t1 hoverable">society</span>
by a Mr. Vincent Francis, and I <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> it reprinted
in Popular Astronomy. The paper is illustrated by
a fine photograph of the spiral nebula in Coma
Berenices, which happens to show very clearly a
condition of nebular growth that I have insisted
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> before now, and which is entirely supported
by the writer I am quoting. You can see in the
photograph how the central <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> is condensing
first before the spirals break up into planets.
The contrary <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> was the defect of the grand
original Laplace discovery. Laplace conceived the
nebula to condense gradually from the outside;
rings being formed, the outermost first, the
central <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> being <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> to the last. By degrees it
was perceived that this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be a very unnature-like process. It was putting the cart
before the horse, or the child before the parent.
Mr. Francis more properly talks of "the parent
sun" in discussing nebular growth.
This <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> department of astronomy has only been
evolved since the development of the telescope.
One may almost say, since the Huggins discovery
that some nebulæ give a purely gaseous spectrum,
making it certain that they were not star
clusters. Since then we have got on rapidly. It
was found, indeed, that some nebulæ, certainly
not resolvable into clusters, gave continuous
spectra. Some consisted of glowing gas and some
of solid particles. Then it became apparent that
most probably all nebulæ were spiral in their
shape, and we approached the conception that

central suns were formed before the planets. Then
(again with the help of Sir William Huggins) we
got at a means of ascertaining the motion of
nebulæ in the line of sight. It is an old story
now, but fascinating as ever. The dark lines in
the spectra of stars are sometimes displaced a
little as compared with those of similar bodies
in the laboratory. If they are displaced towards
the red end of the spectrum, that means that the
star is receding from us. If they are displaced
towards the violet end, that means that the star
is approaching us. The <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> waves are, in fact,
in the one <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> crushed together, in the other
drawn out. Recent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> with this method at the
Lowell observatory has shown that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
Andromeda nebula is approaching us at the rate of
300 kilometres per second, and other nebulæ show
still <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> velocities. But they are so far off,
hopelessly beyond the reach of parallax, almost
too far for guesswork, that some astronomers
incline to think them outside our Universe
altogether, an unacceptable guess in my humble
judgement. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> nebula in Orion is, of
course, the biggest. It covers a region of space
not less than one which <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> only cross in
forty years. But we cannot suggest a maximum
limit of its magnitude, because we have no notion
how far off it is. When we <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> it the nebula in
Orion, we merely mean that we can see it if we
look in the direction of Orion. How far it may be
behind the stars of that group is wholly
uncertain.
How do we see it? Is it self-luminous? There is
<span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> to assume that the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of which it
consists is rarer than the rarest vacuum we can
create here by instrumental means. How can such
attenuated <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> emit light? That is one of the
puzzles we have still to deal with in connection
with this subject. But meanwhile it seems pretty
clear that there are some nebulæ that do not
shine, dark nebulæ that play some mysterious part
in the vast economy of Nature. The nebulous

matter that almost surrounds the Pleiades is
assumed to be dark in the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span> of not being
self-luminous, because its spectrum is identical
with that of the stars to which it belongs,
indicating that it shines with reflected light.
Then the behaviour of Nova Persei, the star which
suddenly blazed out in the constellation Perseus
in 1901, suggested the <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> in that
connection of a vast dark nebula. It lighted up a
region of the sky, the magnitude of which forbade
the idea that there had been any transmission of
<span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> across that space. The phenomenon could
only be due to the velocity of light.
The paper before me makes favourable mention of
the "planetesmal" theory, that has been much
discussed of late in scientific reviews,
bracketing it with the theory that nebulæ that
show planetesmal knots or nuclei have originated
from the collision of worn-out suns. Possibly!
There is <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> to suppose that such collisions
are among Nature's methods in starting a new
nebulae, but it is just as easy to assign
planetesmal knots to the aggregation of <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the spirals of a nebula after it has been
started in business by some other device - the
condensation of etheric <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> from infinite
space, for example.
One more <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> while on this subject concerning a
theory that some astronmers have favoured to the
effect that nebulæ, in some cases at all events,
may be so remote that they constitute Universes
outside our own altogether. "Our" Universe, on
that hypothesis, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> stellar system
embraced by the Milky Way, and shaped, in the
aggregate, like a millstone, the diameter greatly
exceeding its thickness. Nebulæ are more frequent
in the direction of the thickness than in that of
the diameter, and from that condition of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span>
the hypothesis referred to has arisen. It has
always seemed to me to rest on quite insufficient
data, and I am glad to see that an American

astronomer, Professor Barnard, dismisses it with
confidence in its mistaken character. "We <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to
think," he says, "of these nebulæ as being at
such vast distances from us, much beyond the
limits of our universe of stars. Photography has
shown in many ways that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> their distances
must be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> indeed they are often <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> this
<span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> of more distant stars, and that many of
them, perhaps most of them, are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> our
stellar system, and are no farther away than some
of the brighter stars."
In connection with the services photography has
rendered to astronomical science, Professor
Barnard mentions one that is new to me, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
doubtless familiar to experts in that line.
Comets, but faintly perceptible by the telescope
and showing no tails to the observer, are seen to
have tails by the photographic plate. And such
tails will sometimes be seen to drift away from
the comet altogether, the plate following them
for some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> till they dissipate in space. That
fits in beautifully with the theory that comets'
tails consist of minute particles driven off by
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> pressure from the Sun, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> we have to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> into <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> evidence afforded by the plate
that changes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the structure of
comets' tails apparently due to forces emanating
from the comet itself.
2. - <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">WITHIN</span> OR BEYOND OUR UNIVERSE?
The American magazine Popular Astronomy is a very
serious publication, claiming respectful
attention, so I have been much interested in a
statement I <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> in the last number, concerning
the well-known and beautiful globular cluster in
Hercules. This is one of the most wonderful
objects in the heavens when seen through a fine
telescope. It consists of thousands of suns
aggregated <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> in dense mass, so that the
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of all those situated towards the middle is

blended in one mighty glow, only those towards
the periphery of the stupendous assemblage being
discernible as separate points of light. Now it
appears that one astronomer, Mr. Harlow Shapley,
of the Mount Wilson Solar Observatory, has
arrived at the conclusion - by what process of
reasoning we are not told - that the cluster is
distant from us to an extent that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> make its
parallax (if it had one) 0".0001. Its distance
from us, therefore, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be 100,000 <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> years,
and its diameter 1,000 <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> years. According to
this calculation, says Popular Astronomy, "the
cluster is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> another sidereal universe
external to our own." Of course some astronomers
have always been inclined to think that some of
the nebulæ are in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> other universes - a
<span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> I have always been disinclined to adopt. Mr.
Pickering, I see, who contributes to the magazine
just quoted an article on "the sixty finest
objects in the sky," merely mentions the cluster
in Hercules as a very fine object, and does not
discuss Mr. Shapley's calculation. But he treats
the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that most of the clusters lie <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> 5
to 30 degrees of the Galactic equator as adverse
to the theory that they are objects lying beyond
the Galaxy, "although such may nevertheless be
the case."
Now the line of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> that seems to me more
definitely adverse to the theory has to do with
infinitudes of various unthinkable orders, <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span>
in conjunction with ideas suggested by the
visible facts of our own Universe. By that last
phrase I mean all the millions of visible stars
embraced by the Milky Way. The actual diameter of
the space included by that wonderful girdle is a
<span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of conjecture, but roughly the Milky <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span>
is often spoken of as probably about 50,000 <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> away from us in either direction, assuming
that we are somewhere near the centre of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> system, there or thereabouts. Now planetary
distribution <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the Solar System shows us
outer planets <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> at ever increasing distances

from the central Sun. We have not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> worked out
any map showing the distribution of Solar Systems
in the Universe, but the old Hermetic
philosophers had a favourite saying, "As below,
so above." It is applicable to many observed
facts of Nature, and if we start with the
assumption that in the infinites of space there
may or must be other universes, the probability
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be that they are dispersed in space on
principles resembling the dispersal of planets
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the Solar System. The nearest planet to
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> is many times as distant as the Sun's
diameter. The nearest external universe to us
ought on the same principle to be many times the
distance of our Universe's diameter, and that, as
I have said above, is guessed at about 100,000
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> years, so the nearest external universe
ought to be much more than that distance away. It
sounds ridiculous to talk of 100,000 <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span>
as an incredible measurement by <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> of being
too little, but in talking about universes we
must think in terms of infinitude.
All this, I grant, is in the region of the most
unpractical thinking in which we can indulge, but
that is one of the fascinating attributes of
astronomy - it takes us outside the area of lowdown practicalities.
3. - PLANETS, STARS AND ATOMS
Like other sciences astronomy was paralyzed by
the war, and very little new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> was
accomplished during its progress. But some
observations were directed to the question
<span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> the satellites of Jupiter revolve on
their axes or keep only one face to their august
primary. To be more rigidly accurate: do they
rotate on their axes only once in the period of a
revolution round the primary, or more often? The
question is <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of interest, because it is
always cropping up in reference to the interior

planets, Venus and Mercury, and has a very
important bearing on all speculation as to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
in other worlds. The one celestial <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> that
undoubtedly turns only one face to its primary is
our own moon; but by common consent the moon is
to be regarded as a dead planet, <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> we
accept (what seems to be) the foolish theory that
it is a fragment of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> torn off at an
early stage of our planetary life, or the other
theory that it is really the remains of an older
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> than ours, the outer casings of which were
melted off when the nebular condensation that
gave rise to our <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> was in progress. Now we
cannot frame any corresponding hypothesis that
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> for the satellites of Jupiter. Let
me remind the reader of what we know about them.
Leaving out of <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> the later discovered
exterior satellites outside the familiar four and these may be merely masses of meteoric <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span>
caught by the attraction of Jupiter - the wellknown four are bodies of considerable magnitude.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> innermost, Io and Europa, to give them
the names that have been assigned to them, are
somewhat smaller than our moon, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> outer
ones, Ganymede and Callisto, are somewhat larger.
These have been the subject of study by Mr.
Waterfield of the British Astronomical
Association, and he thinks he has discerned
markings which show that Callisto always turns
the same face to Jupiter, while Ganymede, the
outermost of the four, does not seem quite to do
this, but has a period of rotation fifty-nine
minutes less than the period of its revolution
round the primary. It seems presumptuous to
criticize the conclusions of an astronomer using
powerful instruments, but this theory about tidal
action - the assumed cause of the single rotation
idea - is so much in fashion just now that one
can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> believe observers falling in with it,
prone to discover evidence in its favour. My main
objection to it turns on very broad principles
which seem to underlie all reasonable theories of

the Universe. So far as observation enables us to
check the conception, the purpose of
manifestation on the <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> plane is to provide
for the activities of life. All intelligent
thinkers have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> since got beyond the primitive
notion that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> is the only inhabited
world; that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> and stars exist merely for
our sake. We need not jump to the conception that
all other worlds are inhabited by <span class="t1 t4 t8 t16 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> just
like ourselves, but the more closely we study the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> the more we <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> it teeming with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of
one kind or another in every corner, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> in
forms adapted to the most varied conditions of
heat and cold. Directly <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> lifts us above
blank materialism it becomes impossible to rest
content with the idea that any of the other
planets of the Solar System are mere purposeless
masses of dead matter. They must be theatres of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of one kind or another.
Now the theory about turning one face to the
primary has even been applied to the interior
planets of our system. Venus and Mercury are
supposed by some astronomers to turn only one
face to the Sun. But this arrangement <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> make
them to be unfit to be the theatres of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of
any kind. One part <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be burnt to a cinder,
and the other frozen to an unimaginable degree.
The theory as applied to Venus and Mercury is an
insult to the harmonies of Nature, and if
observers think they have detected markings the
motions of which seem to imply the single
rotation arrangement - I do not say tant pis pour
les faits, but tant pis pour the current
interpretation of the facts. As regards the
satellites of Jupiter it is true, even <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
they should really turn one face to the primary,
they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> in their revolution round him turn all
faces in succession to the Sun, so such <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and
warmth as they get from him <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be evenly
diffused. On the other hand, as against Mr.
Waterfield's contention, we have to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> first
the all but universality of the habit celestial

bodies have of turning on their axes. Secondly,
the Jupiter satellites, whatever their origin may
have been, are certainly not what our satellite
is, remains of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> older than the primary.
They are four independent bodies of considerable
magnitude, and we must await the development of
our <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> to a far <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> level than we have
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> reached before expecting to comprehend their
beginnings. "We are ancients of the Earth," etc.,
and the expansion of our faculties since the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span>
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Alfred have bridged the spaces of this
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have indeed seemed
unthinkable for the earlier ancients of that
time. Another advance of corresponding importance
may enable us, or our successors, to cross in
<span class="t1 t7 t9 t12 t14 t19 t29 hoverable">consciousness</span> the spaces of the Solar System.
In another direction of astronomical research
some American attention has been turned to Star
Clusters, with results rather too speculative to
command unqualified trust. Working with
calculations based <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> apparent magnitudes and
probable (!) real luminosities, one observer of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> cluster in Hercules assigns to it a
parallax that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> give the distance across the
cluster as 1,000 <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> years. The calculation is
<span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to fortify the conjecture that such clusters
are distant universes lying in space apart from
our Universe, bounded by the Milky Way. Except as
giving us enormous magnitudes to think about,
speculation of this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> hardly seems
interesting.

META-SCIENCE
We recognize "metaphysics" as a formless realm in
which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> may wander and be <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> of the
tiresome regulations that impede thinking when we
are concerned with Science. But as the
<span class="t14 t24 hoverable">intelligence</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> expands, may there come
into recognition, by degrees, a variety of
thinking that shall be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> "meta-science,"

based on a gradual comprehension of natural <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span>
extending beyond the realm of matter? An article
on "Fatalism and Destiny" in the Times Literary
Supplement, just published as I begin to write,
suggests this question. The author of the article
reaches no definite conclusions, and is mainly
concerned with putting aside, in an attitude of
lordly superiority, what he assumes to be a
tendency among soldiers engaged in the war to
adopt the theory of fatalism. Such theories "are
strange, because they seem like the intrusion of
a forgotten <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> in the rational <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of
our beliefs." The soldier in the midst of
exploding shells is graciously pardoned for
taking refuge in fatalism, and the author
wanders, for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> columns, around the subject,
somehow finding comfort in a distinction between
fatalism and "destiny," the value of which may
not be very clear to the reader.
Now it is quite <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> that the war has made the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> subject, and many others that cling to it,
much more insistent in their demand on attention
than they <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to be in the ancient <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> of
peace. And the wave of interest in super-physical
research and speculation that is spreading
through the intellectual <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> has a force that
seems likely here <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> to bear down the
affectation that the newspapers, as a rule, still
maintain - the pretence of assuming that all
attempts to penetrate the unseen mysteries of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> represent the foolishness of weak minds to
be laughed out of court by the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> in the
street. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> who have lost dear relations in
the war are not easily warned of enquiries that
may throw <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on their fate. And when they make
enquiry they <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> that belief in the possibility
of getting definite news from those who have
"passed on" is not confined, as they had been
told, to weak-minded women and fraudulent
fortune-tellers, but is held as a solid
conviction by a large <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of the most eminent
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of the time. Then they are duly impressed.

Such books as Sir A. Conan Doyle's New
Revelation, Sir William Barrett's Threshold of
the Unseen, and Sir Oliver Lodge's Raymond, and
scores of earlier volumes of equal value and
dignified authorship, make the old-fashioned
attitude of supercilious contempt for
Spiritualism too ridiculous to be kept up much
longer even in Fleet Street. So we may be
approaching a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when metaphysics of the oldfashioned <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> - vague speculation about the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of Thought, and the intangible
philosophies of Hegel or Schopenhaur - will make
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> for the development of a meta-science based
on as definite a foundation of <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> and acquired
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> as the sciences concerned with the laws
governing Matter. As for the fatalism of the
gallant soldier taking his chances with the
shells, if that fortifies his natural pluck we
may <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> be content to let it alone, and perhaps
meta-science will show the, looker-on that even
if the hostile shell bears no definite address,
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> run makes it a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of little ultimate
consequence whom it hits. Meta-science seems to
indicate (even in its present stage of
development) that "no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is found, which only
to one engine bound, falls off but cycles always
around." Tennyson did not stop, when he wrote the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> Voices, to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> out all the consequences of
this hypothesis, but amongst others it suggests
that even if no fatalism guarantees the justice
of each individual <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> on the battle-field,
compensation in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> run is mathematically
certain. And that <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> has the incidental
recommendation of making the Free-will of
humanity the ultimately dominant force in our
progress through the ages.
The most troublesome impediment in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of
meta-science progress arises from the irritation
many otherwise intelligent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> feel when asked
to pay attention to some alleged occurrence that
does not fit in with previous knowledge. When new
phenomena, like the penetrating <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of Röntgen

rays or the susceptibility of electric waves in
the ether to be detected by suitable instruments,
can be reproduced at pleasure, the irritation
soon disappears, and the new discovery passes
into the region of common knowledge. But
sometimes a new discovery, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> genuine, may
for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> be elusive. Consider for a moment the
phenomena of mesmerism, now passing into <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> in
medical practice, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> very imperfectly
understood. The will of the mesmerist can be
proved as often as you like to have a definite
effect on the patient, but by <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> of not
knowing how it operates, irritation prevents the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> in the street from believing the fact, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
he might just as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> disbelieve in the aurora
borealis. But in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> few subjects on which we
can speculate are more attractive to the metascientist than the rationale of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> will.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> generally do not stop to consider that it
is really the original cause of almost everything
that is accomplished in <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> life. No <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span>
has ever been built, no machine has ever been
constructed, unless to begin with some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> will
had started the activities required to
materialize the idea. But when it merely controls
the bricklayer (through the intermediation of
wages), and materializes itself by slow degrees,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> lose sight of the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that Will has been
the origin of the result. Future science has got
to ascertain <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> there may not be some more
direct <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of bringing Will to bear on matter.

ATOMS AND ETHER
I have referred from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to the theory
that the electron is an atom of electricity
supported (in the beginning at all events) by Sir
J.J. Thomson and Sir Oliver Lodge. I have
ventured to repudiate that theory in favour of
its rival - the theory that the electron is an
atom of ether carrying a definite charge of
electricity. Of course, I am very far from being

alone in dissenting from the views of the
dignified authorities just mentioned, but the
atomic theory of electricity must be regarded so
far as the more orthodox <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the two, and a
recent <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> actually heads an article
with the words: "The Atom of Electricity." Now,
of course, one difficulty in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of general
acceptance for the etheric theory of the electron
arises from the <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> that has been widely
entertained concerning the constitution of the
ether itself. According to that conception the
attributes of the ether embody a mass of paradox.
It has been described as non-molecular, denser
than the densest metals and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> utterly
intangible to our senses, perfectly frictionless,
interpenetrating all matter, which is at the same
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> passing through it with planetary velocity.
Then this mysterious medium, at once denser than
the densest solid, and less so than the finest
gases, is undulating all the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> at rates which
paralyze imagination, and giving rise to all the
sensations of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and colour.
But are we capable of framing any theory that
will fit the facts better than the ultra-dense
non-molecular theory? The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Russian chemist,
Mendeléeff, answered that question some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> ago
in a <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> that attracted at the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> less
attention than it deserved, while now, in the
midst of the electron controversy, it really
clamours for attention. It is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> A Chemical
Conception of the Ether. I will endeavour to
explain the argument, content to say, first, that
there can be no one in the scientific hierarchy
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> enough to treat any views of Mendeléeff's
with disdain. He was the originator of the
universally accepted periodic table of the
elements, an arrangement which groups them in
octaves in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> somewhat resembling the grouping
of musical sounds. The elements in each recurring
octave show attributes corresponding to those of
the previous octave. The discovery of this
relationship has given rise to many other

discoveries, for there were gaps in the periodic
table as first drawn up on the basis of such
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> as was then at our disposal. These gaps
pointed to the probability that there ought to be
elements that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> fit them, and with that clue,
one by one most of these have been discovered.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Within</span> recent years, however, the discovery of
the inert gases of the atmosphere - argon,
helium, krypton and the rest - presented chemists
with a new puzzle. There was no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> for them in
the periodic table. Mendeléeff, in the <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> I
have named above, finds the difficulty merely the
introduction to a new and brilliant hypothesis.
All these inert gases <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> a new group or column
by themselves, and their atomic weights fit in
with this arrangement. But there are gaps in the
new column! To make the arrangement symmetrical
there should be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> bodies lighter than helium.
And this condition of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> harmonizes with a
belief Mendeléeff tells us he has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span>
entertained that there ought to be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
"elements," as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> unknown to science, lighter
than hydrogen. He boldly fills up these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> gaps
with bodies x and y, and x, the lighter of the
two, he suggests, is the Ether!
This presentation of the idea by such an
illustrious representative of orthodox chemistry
as Mendeléeff will be of fascinating interest to
a group of thinkers on subjects of this kind,
towards whom, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> they may seem as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> in the
vanguard of wild speculation, my sympathies are
inclined to lean. According to that <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> the
ether is the ultimate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> matter,
from which all the familiar varieties of <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span>
are derived. This <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> establishes the ether
really as the "protyle" of Crookes' famous
hypothesis as to "the Genesis of the Elements."
It seems to me that with Mendeléeff's help we are
bringing a lot of previously scattered
conceptions to a common focus. Arguing from the
analogies of the other columns, Mendeléeff

assigns to x, or the ether, an atomic weight (a
maximum value) of 0.17. Probably, he says, the
weight is far less, as analogy suggests that its
molecule contains only one atom. To interpret the
argument <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> involve the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of mathematical
formulae that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be out of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> here, but it
helps to explain the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that the ether pervades
all space, disregarding the attraction of
planets. The velocity of its atomic vibrations
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> enable it to overcome gravitation. And the
dimensions of the etheric atoms <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be of such
a minute <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> that they obviously may provide a
material basis for the unit charge of electricity
described as the electron, while this <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> subject gets rid of what has always seemed
to me the monstrous absurdity of treating force
as atomic. One might as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> talk of an atom of
gravitation.

ATOMS AND MISUNDERSTANDINGS
Science has so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> been commandeered for the
service of the war, that in reference to some of
its pre-war achievements it has failed to make
further progress. Especially is this the <span class="t1 t3 t5 t16 t19 t25 hoverable">case</span> in
connection with the study of the electron, so
that a <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> I have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> held to be a delusion,
and have often ventured to describe as such,
still commands general acquiescence. I rejoice,
therefore, to observe in America the dawn of a
clear understanding as to the real <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> of that elusive particle. Sir J.J. Thomson
and others still persist in regarding it as an
atom of electricity. A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> and, as it seems to
me, an extremely intelligent article appears in
The Scientific American, under the heading, "The
Relations of <span class="t25 hoverable">Matter</span> and Ether." That all atoms of
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> matter, even the finest, those of
hydrogen, are built up each of many electrons, is
a practically established fact, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> opinions
still differ widely as to the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of electrons
in each. Anyhow, these are supposed, quite

correctly in all probability, to move about
freely <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the space included by the atom,
just as the planets of a solar system move about
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the space embraced by each solar system.
The article before me recognizes the electron as
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> the unit of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> matter, while agreeing
that it is also - or represents also - the unit
volume of electric force. It has a dual aspect. I
must here quote a few lines from the article to
show how the writer glides into the <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> I have
always maintained. "A question of moment here
arises. Can the corpuscles of the ether, its unit
particle, be smaller than this vastly minute
particle of matter? Are we not warranted in
suggesting that these may be in the same category
as far as size is concerned? <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> if this is
admitted as probable we cannot stop here. If
these excessively minute particles, the electron
and the ether corpuscles, are similar in size,
may they not be similar in other directions? In
short, may they not be identical?"
On the basis of this more than reasonable
hypothesis, the writer goes on to draw various
inferences. We start with the conception of the
ether as atomic in its constitution and filling
all space - the raw material from which all
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> is built up. May it not be
susceptible of <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> in different states as
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> exists in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> states,
solid, liquid, and gaseous? Then the atomic
condition in which it fills all space and
transmits the vibrations of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and heat <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
be its gaseous condition. In its liquid condition
it might roll up into drops analogous to those of
water, and become atoms of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> matter! I do
not <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> that idea at all helpful. A much simpler
and more natural <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> treats the aggregation of
etheric atoms into <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> molecules as a
process accomplished by stages. Atomic ether does
not appeal to our <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> senses. Evidently
there must be some minimum <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of etheric
atoms in a molecule to render it so qualified.

Aggregations of lesser <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> still remain
imperceptible to our senses. But it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be
extravagant to assume that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> has no
activities outside those limits. The minor
aggregations of etheric atoms that do not come
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the range of our senses must constitute so
many varieties of molecular ether!
I have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> been convinced that there are such
varieties of molecular ether, and when this comes
to be recognized it will open the door to a flood
of new speculation concerning the phenomena of
light, heat and colour. More than this, it will
put a new and greatly more nature-like complexion
on theories concerning the radiations from the
Sun. We are all familiar with the calculation
showing that the heat radiations of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Sun</span> are
wasted to the extent of some ridiculous
percentage, because so little of them can
actually impinge <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the planets. Suppose no
heat is really wasted! - that what we <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> heat
is an effect developed by the molecular ether
surrounding each planet; that the vibrations of
the atomic ether of interstellar space are not
heat at all! I am not daring to assert this.
Future discovery may follow some quite different
line, but the discovery of molecular ether - at
present merely a profoundly plausible hypothesis
- arising from the discovery of the electron,
seems to me sure of accomplishment now science is
getting out of khaki after the war.
Certainly we shall have to improve our present
senses, or get some more, before we can expect to
be directly cognizant of molecular ether, but we
already deal with many natural phenomena beyond
the range of the senses. Invisible <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and
inaudible sound are favourite subjects for
scientific letures. The ultra-violet rays can be
detected by the photographic plate; the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> of a
whistle, too shrill to be heard, can be observed
by the sensitive flame. Over and above the debt
that optics in the future may owe to the

discovery of molecular ether, it may go a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> towards breaking down the habit of
nineteenth-century science, which <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to make it
so scornful of everything it could neither see,
hear, nor feel. For many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of science, and for
multitudes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> beliefs are based on personal
experience, the new senses requires to enable us
to penetrate the mysteries of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> farther than
this has been done by merely <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> researches,
are recognized as beginning to flicker about here
and there, and are loosely grouped under the
title "clairvoyance." They are already available
for scientific purposes. I hesitate no longer to
include the subject in the range of scientific
developments, partly because - as Sir Oliver
Lodge has put it - those who disbelieve in the
<span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> of clairvoyance do not express an
opinion, but merely show ignorance, and partly
because my own experience has very fully
confirmed that view. Vaguely most <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> imagine
that clairvoyance has to do with fortune-telling
and ghost stories. In reality it is sometimes
directed to genuine scientific research, and, for
example, to the study of the atom. Along this
line of inquiry it has been ascertained (if we
treat the method as reliable) that the <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of
etheric atoms (or electrons) in an atom (or
molecule) of hydrogen is 18. Current scientific
guesses on the subject vary so widely that some
writers put the figure down as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or three, or
even one, while others soar in imagination to the
level of many thousands. The 18 theory is
supported along the line of research that gave
rise to it, by the observation of other atoms
besides those of hydrogen. Many have been
examined, and the result shows that in all such
cases the larger numbers identified with heavier
atoms, when divided by 18, give the recognized
atomic weights of the substances in question. The
discovery is <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of deep significance. It shows
the etheric atom, minute as it is, to be actually
ponderable, and obviously supports the key <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span>
18.

I freely grant that as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> the new senses
required for scientific clairvoyance are so
rarely found in adequate perfection, that they
cannot be checked by <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> in different
laboratories. But if a gradual prima facie belief
in their occasional <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> gains ground,
efforts will assuredly be made to cultivate the
faculty where it exists in embryo, and by degrees
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> scientific research will certainly be pushed
beyond that Threshold of the Unseen that Sir
William Barret writes about with remarkable
effect.

ARCHÆOLOGY
RELICS OF ANTIQUITY
FROM Central America, south of Mexico, as the
country narrows towards the Isthmus of Panama,
the peninsula of Yucatan stretches out eastward.
It is not a region that tempts civilized
immigrants. The climate is not specially
unhealthy, but too hot to be pleasant. Its halfmillion or so of primitive inhabitants have no
mineral wealth. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> endows them with mahoganytrees and tolerates tobacco, cotton, and the
sugar-cane; but the only product which Yucatan
sells to the outer <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is henequin, a kind of
hemp <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> in the manufacture of coarse sackcloth
and hammocks. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> from one point of view, that of
the archæologist, Yucatan is one of the most
interesting regions in the world. It links us
with a past that lies far behind the few <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> that engage the attention of the
Egyptologist, and puts us in touch with a period
of the Earth's history which <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to be regarded
as entirely mythical, but has emerged from that
comfortless moral atmosphere and is now accorded
a grudging recognition by orthodox geology. The
fundamental <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that the Atlantic basin must
once have been, for the most part, continental
land, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> no longer offend any modern
geologist. The idea <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to be ridiculed, but is
now treated as a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of course. Plato,
however, is so far only partially vindicated.
Geology tolerates the theory that there must once
have been an Atlantean land, but declines to have
anything to do with the theory that it was
inhabited. This is the stage in the development
of prehistoric <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> at which Yucatan comes
in. And I am tempted to deal with the subject
because one <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of the Scientific American has
an article about the antiquities of Yucatan that
may help to get attention focused on their
enormous significance.

Yucatan, says the writer, can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the
American Egypt. The ruins of 172 cities, big and
little, have been discovered, and not a quarter
of the territory has been explored. Tropical
vegetation makes the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> difficult. "You might
<span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> a hundred feet of a wonderful old
temple or pyramid a hundred times, and not
discover it, so effectively does the jungle
screen these crumbling monuments of the distant
past." The article goes on to tell us that some
of these ruins must once have been large cities,
with not less than half a million inhabitants in
each one. The writer, who seems to have had
personal experience, has found one pyramid the
most interesting among all these relics of the
past. The steps on one <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> are fairly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span>
preserved, and at the top is a platform, which
was the sacrificial altar. There the priests "cut
out the hearts of living victims." In a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
quadrangle at the foot of the pyramid the
inhabitants of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> to gather to watch
"these festal doings." Around were the "palaces"
of nuns, "for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> special delectation these
sacrifices were made. The nuns were the
aristocrats of ancient Maya society."
The writer does not tell us from what authorities
he derives his information, but anyone who wants
to study the subject further will <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> all he
needs in the books of Dr. Le Plongeon (an
American archæologist, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> with a French
