name), who devoted his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> to the study of
Mexican, and especially Yucatan, antiquities, and
did much more than merely describe remains.
These, like the antiquities of Egypt, are covered
to a large extent with inscriptions in
hieroglyphic character. The hieroglyphics seem
the same as those <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> in Egypt, but the
Egyptologists could make nothing of them.
Egyptian hieroglyphics became intelligible when
the Rosetta stone showed what language they
spelled. But they certainly did not spell Coptic

in Yucatan. The discovery of the language they
did spell is the splendid gift Le Plongeon
bestowed on the archæological world, and because
the results offended the prejudices of the period
(still clinging to the idea that Atlantis was a
fable), they were never properly appreciated. But
the scientific <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> at the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> is more
accessible to new views, which sometimes involve
the restoration of very old views, and the stone
inscriptions of Yucatan are already establishing
some broad conclusions respecting the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of
the old Atlantic continent, compared to whom the
earliest Egyptian and Chaldean civilizations were
recent stages of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> history. In several places
Le Plongeon came <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> inscriptions plainly
describing the final catastrophe that submerged
the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> surviving fragment of the old
Atlantean continent. The date of the catastrophe
is even given with precision. It <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> 8060
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before the period at which the event was
recorded. Plausible guesses as to the date of the
inscriptions add about 3500 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> to the 8000
odd, so it was about 9000 B.C. when the
stupendous cataclysm <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> place. And that only
affected the last then remaining fragment of the
original continent. Yucatan again helps us to
realize in some measure what it must have been in
its entirety. I was once intimate with a friend,
who has since passed away, who was engaged in
important mining operations in Mexico. He told me
that in the course of explorations in that
country and Yucatan, bits of an old road had been
discovered in the midst of what seemed primeval
jungle. These made a dotted line on the map which
extended down through Yucatan, ending abruptly at
the sea coast. But again, farther on, bits were
discovered on islands lying out at sea. Evidently
the old road connected the cities of Mexico and
Yucatan with other important centres in regions
now covered by the Atlantic Ocean. Inscriptions
deciphered by Le Plongeon relate to events
happening in that region. One of his books deals
with the history of a certain "Queen Moo" of the

far-away past, who was driven from her dominions
by usurping brothers, and migrated by a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span>
overland journey to Egypt, where among other
doings she introduced the Sphinx as an emblem
that had previously been what we <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> the
crest of her family. When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is at leisure
again to concern itself with matters of mere
intellectual interest, we may profit by renewed
researches in Yucatan to the extent of framing a
much more complete history of the Atlantean
period; but we shall have to get into the habit
of thinking in millions, instead of thousands, of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> before we can map out in our minds the
stupendous periods through which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> evolution
has passed. Americans do <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> thoroughly
sometimes; and if they begin to realize that,
while the youngest of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> nations in one
way, they are also geographically the oldest,
they may <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> it worth while to devote national
efforts to the further development of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span>
which one of their own countrymen, Le Plongeon,
has begun so well. They are apparently waking up
to the interests of archæology if their leading
scientific paper, the Scientific American, can be
regarded as showing the direction of the wind.
Besides its Yucatan article, recent numbers deal
at length with the antiquities of Ceylon, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
these relate to the yesterdays of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span>
compared with the remains of cities and pyramids
hidden in the jungles of Yucatan.

CATACLYSMS AND EARTHQUAKES
EVERYTHING, says a familiar proverb, comes to
those who wait, even the vindication, at the
<span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of exoteric science, of information
acquired from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> teachers of occultism,
however widely this may seem, at first sight, at
variance with conventional views. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Within</span> the last
few years, something fresh has come out about
earthquakes which has an important bearing on the
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> history of this world, as interpreted by
esoteric teaching and investigation. Almost
everything that stands <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> in encyclopædias
and popular textbooks concerning earthquakes is
now out of date, and under the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> scientific
auspices we are introduced to a <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of this
subject that begins to be in harmony with
Nature's records in reference to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
geographical catastrophes that from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
have altered the face of the globe.
The modern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is indebted to Japan for having
done most up to the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> in the direction
of elucidating the mystery of earthquakes.
Certainly Japan has been better qualified than
any other country to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> a leading part in this
investigation. It is favoured, if that phrase be
admissible, with opportunities for studying
earthquakes which no other country enjoys. On an
average Japan endures <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> a day, not always on
the scale of that which, in 1891, destroyed
10,000 lives, and involved the Government in an
expenditure of 30 million dollars on repairs, but
at all events of one kind or another. Perhaps for
scientific purposes the little earthquakes are
most useful. When towns are shivering in ruins,
and railway viaducts being tied up in knots, the
most zealous seismologist may get confused in his
observations. But anyhow, taking all sorts
together, Japan has plenty of seismological
material to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> with. The examination of this
has become an intellectual fashion in Japan, and
a seismograph is as common an article of luxury

in a Japanese household as a mantelpiece clock
with us. The Government has liberally subsidized
the investigation, and a distinguished English
engineer for some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> past occupied what may be
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Chair of Earthquakes at the Tokio
University.
Professor Milne, the engineer in question, has
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> become the leading authority on earthquakes,
and as such he lectured at the Royal Institution
on Friday evening, a few <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> ago. In the hour
he had at his disposal he did not survey the
various hypotheses that have been put forward
from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> for earthquakes, but
it may be worth while to glance at these here,
for the benefit of readers unfamiliar with the
subject.
The volcanic theory has perhaps been most in
favour. Earthquakes, it has been assumed, have
been underground disturbances that have not been
near enough to the surface to break out as
eruptions, but have nevertheless shaken and
dislocated the upper strata. Another notion has
been that they were due to the influx of seawater into internal cavities in the crust of the
Earth. Steam, at a <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> temperature, it was
supposed, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be engendered in this way, and an
earthquake <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> ensue on the principle of an
explosion in a steam-boiler. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> another theory
suggested the reaction of certain chemical
ingredients coming into contact in the interior
cavities of the Earth's crusts. Gases at a <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span>
pressure were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> supposed to be developed, and
hence the explosive energy displayed. All these
conjectures are equally dispelled by the results
of the Japanese investigations. Professor Milne
did not think it was worth while even to notice
the steam and chemical theories, but he paid the
volcanic theory the compliment of a specific
repudiation. We have arrived at the conclusion,
he declared, that earthquakes have nothing
whatever to do with volcanoes. They are not local

phenomena at all, not due to causes engendered in
the neighbourhood where they occur, but to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
waves or pulsations to which the crust of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is constantly subject, the effect of which
is not perceived unless some rupture ensues. The
huge, slow waves or undulations are described in
the new terminology of earthquake science as
"bradyseismic" disturbances, and they are going
on just as freely and steadily in quiet regions,
where earthquakes in the ordinary <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span> of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> are unknown, as in regions like Japan, or
the west ocean of South America, where they are
frequent. But now and then it happens that as the
bradyseismic wave encounters some irregular
resistance or weakness in strata it disturbs,
something gives way, something cracks, and then a
shiver goes through the region where that occurs.
Such a shiver may in a few moments destroy
property worth millions, and lives by the
thousand.
Another influence productive of earthquake
disturbance is described by Professor Milne as a
"secular crush and flow." Observation has shown
how wonderfully responsive the solid <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is to
changes of weight pressing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> it. The
deposition and evaporation of dew in the evening
produces a sensible movement of the ground sensible, that is to say, to the new and
delicately adjusted seismographs in <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> for such
observations. What, then, must be the effect of
the regular denudation of continents that is
always going on, and of the deposition of the mud
carried down by rivers on the bottom of the sea?
The latest conjecture is that this pressure is
sufficient to cause an actual flow of solid rock
away from the regions of greatest pressure. We
know, of course, that solid and viscous are
merely relative expressions. Treacle is only more
viscous than lead, which in the ordinary course
of bullet-making is now squeezed, cold, out of
holes by hydraulic pressure, and flows like so
much putty. Lead is only more viscous than steel.

Ice, it is now suggested, is only more viscous
than granite. Every solid substance is viscous in
one degree or another. Imagine a thick, evenly
spread bed of soft clay; then imagine a weight
put down on any part of the surface. One sees at
once that the weight <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> sink into the clay,
more or less, and that part of the clay beneath
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be squeezed out laterally, heaving up the
surface elsewhere. That is just what takes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
in connection with the secular flow of the
Earth's lower strata, and here we get into
relations with a <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> cause of
earthquakes, the effect of which, in causing a
rupture of the superior strata somewhere, is
similar, apparently, to the effect of the
bradyseismic wave.
As a <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of fact, earthquakes are most
numerous in those parts of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> where the
seashore falls very abruptly into deep ocean.
That occurs to the eastward of Japan, and also on
the western <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> of South America. But one of the
most interesting facts now <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> is
that wherever an earthquake takes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> the shock
of it is really felt all over the rest of the
world. The vibration passes, apparently, through
the solid <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of the Earth. We must leave off
talking about the crust of the Earth. That phrase
is derived from an early hypothesis that has been
discredited for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> while - that has been at
variance with all the <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> teaching
permeating theosophical information, and is now
clearly untenable in the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the new
seismology. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> is
plainly capable of transmitting vibrations of the
kind that are transmitted by <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of the utmost
rigidity. There is evidence to show that the
earthquake waves are communicated from one part
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to another with definite velocities,
and they do not make their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> round the globe,
they <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> through it by the most direct line that
can be drawn from one point to another. The rate
at which the vibrations are transmitted is

extraordinarily high, in some instances
approaching a speed of twelve kilometres per
second, or double the rate at which a wave of
compression could <span class="t6 t9 t13 t15 t17 t18 t23 t28 t29 hoverable">pass</span> through steel or glass.
Further than this, if this direct line passes
only through a shallow segment of the Earth, the
rate of transmission is less rapid than if it
passes through a greater mass. That is to say,
the most rapid transmission <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be straight
through, from any given point to its antipodal
point. I say "would be" because up to the present
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> seismological observations have not been
carried out extensively enough to have provided
for antipodal stations corresponding to the
regions of most frequent disturbance, but the
character of all observations that have been made
at places widely separated indicates an
increasing velocity in direct ratio with the
depth through the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> followed by the course of
transmission.
The trustworthiness of the inferences already
arrived at as regards the rate at which the
vibrations travel, is shown by the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that
already it is possible to tell, from observations
in England, at what moment an earthquake has
<span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in Japan. At Professor Milne's
seismological observatory in the Isle of Wight,
he has been enabled on some occasions to
anticipate the announcements of the telegraph in
reference to earthquakes in Japan. Once he
announced - before any telegraphic news had been
received - that such an event had <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> on
a certain date, at such and such an hour and
minute. When the news came in the ordinary course
of things, it turned out that he had been right
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> an error of one minute only. In another
case, when the papers announced that a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
earthquake had <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> at Kobe, his
instruments had given no indications to
correspond. He declared the news to be
inaccurate, and in due <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> it turned out to have
been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> foundation.

The importance of all this as bearing on
questions in which theosophical students are
interested, has to do with the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> it throws on
the old standing question of cataclysms. The
drift of conventional scientific thinking for
some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> past has been in the direction of what
geologists <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> uniformity. We do not see
cataclysms going around us at present, but we do
see the gradual operation of forces that over
very <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> periods of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> may be supposed capable
of superinducing the changes of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
distribution that must assuredly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> place. Rain
and the rivers are continually washing down the
soil of continents to the sea. In this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> ocean
beds are being filled up, and exising <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">land</span>
surfaces denuded. Shores in some places are being
eaten away by the sea, and in other places slowly
raised, so that former beaches are now hoisted
half-way up <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> cliffs. In time, it is supposed
by the uniformitarians, these gradual processes
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> suffice to <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> for the largest changes
we like to imagine. They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not account,
however, for the violent convulsions of which
theosophical teachers <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> as having happened in
the past and of which, indeed, advancing
theosophical students, beginning to be able to
apply their own powers of observation to remote
historical investigation, are enabled to <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span>
with much detail. Those of us who comprehend the
trustworthiness of investigation of that sort may
have no doubt about the fact, <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> modern
science <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> recognizes it or not; but it is
always gratifying to derive from modern science
confirmation of theosophic teaching. And while
the local theory of earthquakes held the field,
no such confirmation was forthcoming in reference
to such events in the past as the destruction of
Atlantis. Now we begin to perceive along what
road the ultimate developments of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> will converge towards the conclusions
of occult investigation. The bradyseismical waves
of the new seismology fit in perfectly with a

belief that, at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> intervals of time, natural
convulsions may occur on a very much larger scale
than that of any which have been recorded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span>
historic periods. Some of these, of course, have
been fairly big. The Lisbon catastrophe not only
killed 60,000 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> at the seat of its chief
activity, but distributed its influence
perceptibly over an area, according to Humboldt's
calculation, four times as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> as Europe. As we
know now, its influence must really have been
felt all over the world, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> in distant places
too slightly to be measured by instruments then
in use. The Calabrian earthquake of 1783
destroyed 40,000 lives. But, after all, disasters
of this magnitude are not commensurable with the
least of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Atlantean catastrophes.
According to the Troano manuscript, translated by
Dr. Le Plongeon, sixty million <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> perished in
the final Poseidonis convulsion, which changed an
inhabited territory, measuring over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span>
miles one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> by about one <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> hundred
the other, into so much ocean bed. For <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> to
whom the six or seven <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> of the
historic period seem to afford a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> basis for
generalization, it naturally appears unlikely
that if our Lisbon earthquake is the champion
convulsion for that period, anything so out of
proportion with it should have <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> six or
seven <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> earlier.
The bradyseismic wave system, <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> in
conjunction with the secular flow of rocks, puts
a new complexion on all such speculation.
Everything we know about vibrations tends to show
that in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> these movements are superimposed
one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> another. In electrical phenomena this is
certainly the case, and in <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
principle of multiplex telegraphy is built <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
that idea. Occult investigation into the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span>
of the ultimate atom points to the same kind of
complexity there. In the motion of the planetary
bodies we have to recognize similar movements
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> movements. The diurnal rotation of the

Earth is superimposed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the much slower
precessional, or <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> rotation. Whatever the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> pulsations of the Earth's surface may be
due to, it is more than imaginable that a larger
and slower pulsation passes through it at longer
intervals. Earthquakes of the secondary order,
like those which afflicted Lisbon in the last
century, are due apparently to a rupture of some
rock <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> giving <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to the pressure of one of
the relatively minor undulations of the strata
below. A pulsation of greater magnitude may
easily be supposed to create a superficial
disturbance on a different scale altogether, one
for which, perhaps, a long-continued operation of
the secular rock flow has prepared the way.
In addressing theosophical readers, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
seems desirable here on the question <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> such
catastrophes as those of the Atlantean age should
be attributed to causes of uniform regularity, or
to the intervention of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> authorities
connected with the government of the world, at
crises when the depravity of mankind renders the
extinction of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on a large scale a necessity
of the situation. The destruction of Atlantis has
generally been talked of with reference to some
such intervention. But everything we learn about
the evolution of the race to which we belong
points to the synchronism between the regular
progress of natural <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> and the development of
crises in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> destiny. The recognition of this
synchronism will not interfere with our
simultaneous recognition of <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> will as regards
the individual. No one is bound to give <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> to
the temptations of his race or period in
evolution, but taking the stupendous numbers
concerned into account, it is certain that so
many, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> a limit of error, will follow the
stream, while so many will strike out a path for
themselves. In Atlantean ages the course of the
stream was in a direction which, at all events
for us, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be the direction of evil. Sooner or
later it was inevitable that a condition of

things should be developed which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> require a
violent remedy. One need hardly be surprised to
<span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> that the remedy under those circumstances
was provided for by a geological crisis, towards
which the Earth's strata had been moving all the
while that the Atlantean majority were working
out the moral necessity of their own destruction.

POETRY AND THEOSOPHY
A RECENT article in the Theosophist deals with a
subject that has often engaged my thoughts. Much
poetry is deplorably unspiritual by <span class="t1 t3 t8 t25 hoverable">reason</span> of
treating <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> as a dismal finality, instead of
being the gateway to new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> - "Mors janua
vitæ." As Mr. Cousins puts it, a "revolution in
Western literary arts <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> about if
the idea, say of reincarnation, could be given as
<span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> as the current idea of a
single life." I quite agree, but meanwhile a
grand result <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be achieved if poetry could
help the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to realize that before attaining
reincarnation, there is a period of happiness in
the more immediate future awaiting all decent
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> on the astral plane. In our earlier
teaching this was a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deal slurred over, as
still wider aspects of <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> claimed
interpretation first. But in a recent book, In
the Next World, I have endeavoured to show how
vivid, delightful, and fairly protracted may be
that astral experience preceding not merely the
return to <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> life, but preceding any
experiences on <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> planes that may await any
given Ego. Therefore, the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> poetical
reform I should like to see <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be one that
should encourage <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t12 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">thought</span> to range beyond the
grave, instead of burrowing incessantly in that
unimportant region.
Consider, for instance, one of the most beautiful
passages in all poetry, Moore's "Farewell to
Araby's Daughter" at the end of The Fireworshippers. Its beauty resides entirely in the
form, not in the substance. It is altogether a
lament. Its exquisite language is concerned
entirely with the dear girl's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> lying at the
bottom of the sea. The Peris who <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> the dirge
are solely engaged with their efforts to beautify
its bed.

shell in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> hollow-wreathed chamber
of ocean, by moonlight have slept.

dive where the gardens of coral lie darkling,
plant all the rosiest stems at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thy</span> head,
seek where the sands of the Caspian are sparkling
gather their gold to strew over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thy</span> bed.

For pure mellifluous beauty of expression those
verses will rank with anything in literature, but
what a ghastly blunder it was for Moore to spend
his genius on thoughts about the dead girl's
body, instead of thinking about the girl! I have
endeavoured to suggest a paraphrase of his superb
effusion - what he might have given us instead if
he had come <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the range of Theosophical
teaching. To guard against misunderstanding, let
me explain that I am not supposing that any
rhymes of mine can rival Moore's in form. Moore imperfectly appreciated in these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> - was,
among all poets that have ever lived, the supreme
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> of versification. Tennyson, a far grander
poet as regards thought, has here and there
touched Moore's perfection of form, but, as a
composer of music in words, Moore is facile
princeps. My effort is a concrete expression of
wonder as to what might have been the character
of his "Farewell" had he known what (I think) I
know about <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> immediately after death. Here are
the verses. They are not a "Farewell," but a
"Greeting."
Welcome, thrice welcome, O Araby's daughter!
A glad <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> greeted her advent above.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> cast away in Oman's green <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
Is needed no more in this bright real of love.

'Twas fair for a while, giving transient expression
For Earth's passing <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> pure and white,
But that is now rescued from fleshly possession
Arrayed in a far fairer vesture of light.
That agonized plunge in the dark dreary ocean
Was no coward flight from pain, peril, or strife;
A gift to your lover, an act of devotion,
A <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> laid on the altar of life.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">World</span> <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> behind you will weep o'er your story,
Will fancy that You lie asleep in the wave;
For you that has proved but the gateway of glory,
The dawn of new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> wih the pure and the brave
They bid you farewell, those who mourn your wild daring,
They shudder to think of your cold, lonely bed.
Oh! could we but tell them how <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> you are faring,
They'd share in your joy now your <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> is dead.
In depths of the sea that will soon melt and vanish,
On heights of the Astral your beauty revives,
The grief that once marred it this glow will soon banish,
With all that disfigured Earth's lowlier lives.
Nor shall you be saddened to think of their sadness
Who even may weep at your pitiful fate;
Now weeping, the better they'll share in your gladness
When they too inherit the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> they await.
No graven stone tells where the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> that once bound you
Restores to the Earth, from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Earth</span> what it drew;
How little you care, as the scenes now around you
Enchant your new senses with limitless view.
But see! who approaches? Reborn with new vigour,
How needless 'twas even his fate to deplore,
With rapture he sees you! No flames could disfigure
That form. It is he! 'tis your lover once more.

There are many other well-known poems dealing
with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> that might be recast along similar
lines: "The Burial of Sir John Moore," for
example, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> those rather ponderous verses do
not attract one to the task. Poetry, indeed, is
dotted all over with blemishes due to ignorance
of astral conditions, and perhaps it may be
admitted that even Theosophical literature, apart

from poetry altogether, has sometimes tended to
chill imagination by leaving too much out of
<span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> the gradual character of the transition
from this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> towards the illimitable future of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> evolution. Natural <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> is very patient with
the pardonable cravings of personality, and lofty
teaching is sometimes made to seem repellent by
neglecting this profound truth, as was
illustrated by a remark I once <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> of, made by
a lady who said she was much attracted to
Theosophy but could not be a Theosophist because
she loved her husband and her children! Once can
easily understand the peculiar variety of
foolishness on the part of some ill-qualified
exponent of Theosophy who gave her that
impression. The charms of the <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> astral <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
ought to <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> more frequent description in
Theosophical literature, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as in the poetry
of the future.

NOTE
THE substance of some of the various essays in
this <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> has appeared in The Nineteenth Century,
The Messenger (California), The Vahan, The
Pioneer (Allahabad), Lucifer, and The
Theosophist. "Expanded Theosophical Knowledge"
was originally published as a pamphlet by the
Theosophical <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> Shop, 42, George Street,
Edinburgh. "Theosophical Teachings Liable to be
Misunderstood" and "The Pyramids and Stonehenge"
appear among the Transactions of the London Lodge
of the Theosophical Society. The substance of the
"Super-Physical Laws of Nature" and "The <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">Higher</span>
Occultism" was delivered in addresses to the
Eleusinian Society, since merged in the London
Lodge of the Theosophical Society.
